entry.title: Who is Transactionl aimed towards?
entry.summary:
Transactionl is aimed towards small/medium businesses that need transactional email across multiple websites and applications, with top deliverability at a low cost.

Example use-cases

Some examples of customers using Transactionl are:

  • WordPress, Drupal & Joomla: Our customers use Transactionl with popular content management systems. Some examples are password resets, post notifications, comment notifications, and WordPress update notifications.
  • E-commerce websites: Our customers use Transactionl with applications such as Shopify and WooCommerce. Some examples are order confirmations, shipping notifications, and delivery updates.
  • Agencies: Many of our customers are agencies that manage websites and applications on behalf of multiple clients. Some example use-cases are CRMs such as Salesforce and Zoho CRM, and e-commerce websites using WooCommerce and Shopify.

üí° Did you know:¬†Transactionl is perfect low-cost solution for agencies that need transactional email across multiple applications and websites. Our agency plan provides unlimited mailboxes and domains, all at a very low cost.

entry.title: Setup Guide*
entry.summary:
1. Purchase a package

To purchase a package, navigate to my.transactionl.com

Any starting domain will work. This will be your 'default' domain added to your account. Depending on your package, you may add other domains.

2. Configuring domains

Adding domains is managed at the DirectAdmin panel at everest.mailadmin.transactionl.com

Adding a domain

To add a domain name to Transactionl, log into the DirectAdmin panel at everest.mailadmin.transactionl.com, then:

1. On the sidebar, click Account Manager -> Domain Setup to get to the Domain Management page. Next, click on + Add New:

2. Your screen will now display the "Create Domain" screen. Enter your chosen domain (or subdomain) name in the 'Domain' text box. Ensure Secure SSL is selected.

3. Configuring DNS

For this, you'll need to copy your SPF and DKIM records from the Transactionl DirectAdmin panel and paste them into your DNS records for your chosen domain.

üí° Tip: Your DNS records can be found at your domain registrar (such as GoDaddy or NameCheap), or at another DNS host (such as CloudFlare or ClouDNS).

If you've set up a nameserver at your domain registrar, your DNS records will be managed at the same place your nameserver is set to (i.e. If you've set your nameserver to john.ns.cloudflare.com, your DNS records are managed at CloudFlare).

3.1. At Transactionl (DirectAdmin)

1. On the sidebar, click Account Manager -> DKIM & SPF Records to get to the DNS Management page:

2. Take note of your DKIM record, this will need to be copied to your DNS host:

3.2. At your DNS Host (e.g. Cloudflare)

This example uses Cloudflare to set up DNS records. Your DNS provider may look slightly different, however it's essentially the same steps.

1. Navigate to where you manage your DNS records. For Cloudflare, this is yourdomain.tld -> DNS -> Records.

2. Add your DKIM record (from the steps above from DirectAdmin). This must be the "TXT" type. You may set TTL as either 3600 or Auto.

3. Add Transactionl's SPF record. This is:
"v=spf1 include:mxlogin.com -all"

4. Configuring mailboxes

Adding mailboxes is managed at the DirectAdmin panel at everest.mailadmin.transactionl.com

entry.title: What are my SMTP/IMAP/POP3 details?
entry.summary:
In most cases, all you require is SMTP to use Transactionl with your application.

Email Address: The email address you created in DirectAdmin (e.g. user@example.com)
Password: The password you set for the mailbox in DirectAdmin.
Server/Hostname: everest.mxrouting.net
SMTP SSL Port: 465 (Recommended)
SMTP Non-SSL/STARTTLS: 25, 587, 2525 (Not recommended due to security)

If you'd like to use your own email client instead of webmail to read/delete bounce emails, you can use the following protocols/ports:

IMAP SSL: 993
IMAP Non-SSL: 143
POP3 SSL: 995
POP3 Non-SSL: 110

entry.title: Do you allow outgoing marketing emails?
entry.summary:
No. You may not use Transactionl to send outgoing marketing emails, SPAM, unsolicited email or cold outreach.

Our customers rely on our services for reliable inbox placement and deliverability. The first step taken to achieve this is by keeping email marketers away from our services.

You may only use Transactionl for transactional email - after all, it's in our name.

entry.title: How do I use Transactionl with WordPress?*
What are your limits?
entry.summary:
If you're wondering about our service limits and how they work, you're in the right place.

What are your domain limits?

There's none! All plans provide use of unlimited domains.

What are your mailbox limits?

This depends on your plan. We have three simple plans:

Solo - 1 Mailbox
Pro - 10 Mailboxes
Agency - Unlimited Mailboxes

What are your sending limits?

Our sending limit is simple: 300 outgoing emails per hour, per mailbox/use case.

You may not use multiple mailboxes for the same purpose to circumvent this limit for the same use case. However, you can (and should!) use separate mailboxes for each separate purpose/use case.

‚ÑπÔ∏è If you need to send more than 300 transactional emails per hour, please let us know - we can increase this limit on a case-by-case basis. This is because our outgoing email provider enforces limits to prevent abuse by spammers and maintain high levels of deliverability.

For a more detailed explanation, please see below:

Allowed ‚úÖ
form@example.com - Contact Form Notifications
website@example.com - WordPress Website Notifications
billing@example.com - Billing Notifications
form@examplepetstore.com - Gener
billing@examplepetstore.com -¬†
website@examplepetstore.com

In this example, our customer has separated their mailboxes for different purposes for example.com and examplepetstore.com, so they can send up to 300 outgoing emails/hour for each different purpose/use case.

‚ÑπÔ∏è Whilst they could use just one mailbox per domain or for multiple use cases, they have created separate mailboxes for each¬†purpose to avoid reaching the 300/hour limit.

Not allowed ‚ùå

billing@example.com - Used for billing at example.com
billing2@example.com - Used to exceed the 300/h limit
billing3@example.com - Used to exceed the 300/h limit

In this example, our customer is using 3 different mailboxes for the same purpose/use case, in order to circumvent the send limit. This is not allowed, and is considered abuse of our service.

If you are reaching need to send more than 300 transactional emails per hour for your use case, please get in touch to discuss increasing your limits.
